src:
El genocidio de Ruanda llega ante la justicia belga
04 Nov 2019, 11:00 by Gregoire Lory  



Desde hace 25 años, Martine Beckers lucha para que se haga justicia.
Su hermana, su cuñado y su sobrina fueron asesinados durante el genocidio de Ruanda.
Finalmente, esta semana, la justicia belga sienta en el banquillo al hombre que presuntamente avisó a las milicias y denunció a su familia.
"Espero, sin acabar de creermelo, que quien jugó un papel determinante en este asesinato reconozca su responsabilidad. Espero entender mejor. Espero que finalmente se haga justicia", explica Beckers.
Todavía recuerda aquel domingo de 1994. Eran las ocho de la mañana cuando recibió una llamada de teléfono anunciándole la muerte de su familia. Vivían en Ruanda desde hacía 17 años.
Claire, su hermana, tenía un negocio de helados. Su marido, Isaie, era ingeniero. Y su sobrina Katia era una gran deportista llena de vitalidad. No tuvieron tiempo de huir.
"Las milicias, conocidas como Interahamwe, llegaron y les asesinaron. Mi hermana cayó la primera, recibió un disparo en la cabeza", recuerda.
En el tribunal de Bruselas, tan sólo se juzgará a una persona: Fabien Neretsé. Pero para Martine no fue el único responsable. Los soldadeos de Naciones Unidas estaban acuartelados a tan sólo 500 metros de su casa. Pero dijeron que no podían ir a buscarla porque era demasiado peligroso.
"Ella tenía mucho, mucho miedo. Esperaba que los soldados que estaban acuartelados cerca de su casa, los soldados belgas de la MINUA, las fuerzas de Naciones Unidas, irían a salvarla. Que la embajada, el consulado, intervendrían para protegerla. Pero no hicieron nada", se lamenta.
La ONU calcula que entre abril y julio de 1994, unas 800.000 personas fuerons asesinadas durante el genocidio ruandés.
text:
The Rwandan genocide comes before Belgian justice
04 Nov 2019, 11:00 by Gregoire Lory



For 25 years, Martine Beckers has been fighting for justice.
His sister, brother-in-law and niece were killed during the Rwandan genocide.
Finally, this week, the Belgian justice sits on the bench to the man who allegedly notified the militias and denounced his family.
"I hope, without believing it, that whoever played a decisive role in this murder will recognize their responsibility. I hope to understand better. I hope justice is finally done," Beckers explains.
He still remembers that Sunday of 1994. It was eight o'clock in the morning when he received a phone call announcing the death of his family. They had lived in Rwanda for 17 years.
Claire, her sister, had an ice cream business. Her husband, Isaie, was an engineer. And his niece Katia was a great athlete full of vitality. They didn't have time to run away.
"The militias, known as Interahamwe, arrived and killed them. My sister dropped the first one, was shot in the head," he recalls.
In the Brussels court, only one person will be judged: Fabien Neretsé. But for Martine he was not solely responsible. The United Nations welds were quartered just 500 meters from their home. But they said they couldn't go looking for her because it was too dangerous.
"She was very, very afraid. She hoped that the soldiers who were quartered near her home, the Belgian soldiers of the MINUA, the United Nations forces, would go to save her. That the embassy, the consulate would intervene to protect her. But no They did nothing, "he laments.
The UN estimates that between April and July 1994, some 800,000 people were killed during the Rwandan genocide.
